Is anomalous vertical motion in WAIS Ice Streams tied to subglacial water transport?
Is anomalous vertical motion in WAIS Ice Streams tied to
subglacial water transport?

Laurence Gray, Ian Joughin, Slawek Tulaczyk, Vandy Blue Spikes, Bob Bindschadler and Ken Jezek.
Laurence Gray, Ian Joughin, Slawek Tulaczyk,
Vandy Blue Spikes, Bob Bindschadler and Ken Jezek.

picture.caption: Area A1 includes an area of the Kamb Ice Stream (“C”). Area A2 includes a tributary of the Bindschadler Ice Stream (“D”). L1 and L2 are lidar flight lines flown by SOAR in 1998 and 2000.

page.title:
Phase images from both ascending and descending SRI pairs. Note that the patterns, which reflect ‘line-of-sight displacement’, are different in the 2 geometries except for the concentric rings over the position of the surface deflation.
Phase images from both ascending and
descending SRI pairs. Note that the
patterns, which reflect ‘line-of-sight
displacement’, are different in the 2
geometries except for the concentric rings
over the position of the surface deflation.

Airborne laser altimetry also shows surface uplifts and depressions. While the height changes (~4 m vs. 0.5 m) and time span (2 years vs. 24 days) are larger, the differences are similar in shape to those based on interferometry.
Airborne laser altimetry also shows
surface uplifts and depressions. While
the height changes (~4 m vs. 0.5 m) and
time span (2 years vs. 24 days) are
larger, the differences are similar in
shape to those based on interferometry.

picture.caption: Lidar data courtesy of the SOAR facility, U Texas, and NSF.
picture.name: Image43

picture.caption: Data from Spikes et al. Thickness changes on Whillans Ice Stream and Ice Stream C, West Antarctica, derived from laser altimeter measurements. J. Glaciol. 49, 165, 2003.
picture.name: Image44

page.title:
The colored dots are surface and bed elevations from the CASERTZ program. There appears to be a dip in both the surface and bed elevations at the site of the surface deflation.

Reducing Canada's vulnerability to climate change - ESS
Reducing Canada's vulnerability to climate change - ESS
page.title:
Summary
Summary
page.enlisting:
• • We have shown vertical displacement of surface ice in tributary flow in West Antarctica. The vertical movement is up to ~ 2 cm day, and could not be maintained on the long term. Ice volume continuity, the shape of the features, and the position of the areas over hydropotential wells suggest that the relatively rapid height change could be due to movement of pockets of subglacial water. • The results may help explain the recent borehole observations of near bottom debris layers, and a 1.5m layer of subglacial water. • Finally, we seem to have a tenuous (?) handle on subglacial water movement. … further systematic work is required. •
•
• We have shown vertical displacement of surface ice in tributary flow in West Antarctica. The vertical movement is up to ~ 2 cm day, and could not be maintained on the long term. Ice volume continuity, the shape of the features, and the position of the areas over hydropotential wells suggest that the relatively rapid height change could be due to movement of pockets of subglacial water. • The results may help explain the recent borehole observations of near bottom debris layers, and a 1.5m layer of subglacial water. • Finally, we seem to have a tenuous (?) handle on subglacial water movement. … further systematic work is required. • We have shown vertical displacement of surface ice in tributary flow in West Antarctica. The vertical movement is up to ~ 2 cm day, and could not be maintained on the long term. Ice volume continuity, the shape of the features, and the position of the areas over hydropotential wells suggest that the relatively rapid height change could be due to movement of pockets of subglacial water.
